Option B. Narrow vascular pedicle: The "string" part of the "egg-on-a-string" appearance refers to the narrow mediastinum, which is due to the narrow vascular pedicle, a common finding in TGA.

 

Option C. Right atrial enlargement: Right atrial enlargement: Enlargement of the right atrium is seen in TGA due to the abnormal circulation pattern but is a rare feature.
Both atria can enlarge in TGA, but left predominates
With mixing lesions (VSD, ASD), right atrial enlargement can happen

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "egg-on-a-string" appearance on a chest X-ray is characteristic of Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA), and pulmonary venous hypertension is not a typical finding in this condition.

choices.text: Insert a central venous catheter as the initial IV access of choice

questions.text: Before transferring the patient to the operating theatre, which of the following is necessary to do for a 60-year-old man who has been experiencing abdominal pain for the past six hours, has a BP of 84/50mmHg, RR of 26/min, saturation of 92% with 6 L of oxygen, and has extraluminal air in the abdomen on radiograph? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer 2 litres of crystalloid infusion

 

This is the correct option. The patient's low blood pressure (84/50 mmHg) and extraluminal air in the abdomen suggest a possible abdominal catastrophe, such as a perforated viscus. Administering crystalloid fluids is essential to address hypovolemia and improve blood pressure. The goal is to stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status and then perform an emergency laparotomy and repair the perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubate the patient: While intubation may be necessary in some cases of severe respiratory distress or respiratory failure, it is not indicated in this situation.

 

Option B. Insert a central venous catheter as the initial IV access of choice: While establishing intravenous (IV) access is important for administering fluids and medications, inserting a central venous catheter is a more invasive procedure and not the initial step. Peripheral IV access can be established quickly and is usually sufficient for initial resuscitation.

 

Option D. Verify the diagnosis with CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography): While a CT scan may be necessary for confirming the diagnosis and identifying the specific issue, it is not the initial step in managing a patient in this critical condition. Stabilizing the patient's vital signs and addressing potential hypovolemia should come first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the given clinical scenario, volume resuscitation is crucial for maintaining BP as the patient has no history of trauma, indicating a possible bowel perforation.
  • Peripheral large-bore cannula may be used for initial volume resuscitation, and a central venous catheter may be required if vasopressors are planned.
  • Intubation may not be necessary since the patient is maintaining saturation.
  • CT scan may not be necessary as the provisional diagnosis of bowel perforation has already been established, and the patient's vital signs should be considered.

questions.text: A young male presents to surgery OPD with a verrucous lesion over the penis as shown in the image. On examination, inguinal lymph nodes are not enlarged. What is the management of choice in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) Partial penectomy

 

  • The question depicts a case of verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor.
  • Verrucous carcinoma is a rare type of squamous cell carcinoma that is locally aggressive but has a low potential for metastasis.
  • The lesion typically appears as a large, exophytic, cauliflower-like growth.
  • The management of choice for verrucous carcinoma of the penis is partial penectomy.
  • This surgical procedure involves removing the affected portion of the penis to ensure complete excision of the tumor while preserving as much of the penile structure and function as possible.
  • This approach helps in preventing local recurrence and provides a definitive treatment for the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO2 laser ablation: CO2 laser ablation is a treatment option for in-situ carcinoma, such as Bowen’s disease or penile intra-epithelial neoplasm. It is effective in treating superficial lesions but is not adequate for managing verrucous carcinoma due to its deeper and locally invasive nature.

 

Option B. Podophylline: Podophylline is a topical treatment commonly used for genital warts caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). It is not appropriate for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires a more definitive surgical approach.

 

Option C. Topical 5-Fluoro uracil: Topical 5-Fluoro uracil is used in the treatment of in-situ carcinoma or Bowen’s disease. It is not suitable for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires surgical excision due to its locally invasive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor, is best managed by partial penectomy to ensure complete removal of the tumor and prevent local recurrence.
  • This approach is necessary due to the locally aggressive behavior of the tumor, which cannot be adequately treated with topical or minimally invasive methods.

questions.text: What would be the next suitable examination for a chronic smoker, aged 40, who is experiencing blue discoloration of the toe and intermittent claudication? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Duplex scan

 

The duplex scan is a type of ultrasound that combines traditional ultrasound with Doppler ultrasound. It can visualize the structure of blood vessels and the flow of blood within them. It is non-invasive, doesn't require the use of contrast media, and can provide immediate results. Given the patient's symptoms of blue discoloration of the toe (suggesting compromised blood flow) and intermittent claudication (pain in the legs while walking, indicating peripheral artery disease), a duplex scan is an excellent first choice to evaluate the patency of the arteries and the location and severity of any blockages. For a chronic smoker with these symptoms, a duplex scan is a commonly used initial diagnostic tool to evaluate peripheral arterial disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT Angiography: Computed tomography angiography (CTA) is a diagnostic tool that combines X-ray technology with computer imaging to visualize blood flow in the arteries. While it can provide detailed images of blood vessels and can identify blockages or other vascular problems, it requires the injection of a contrast medium, exposes the patient to radiation, and might not be the first-line diagnostic tool in this scenario.

 

Option B. MR Angiography: Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is a type of MRI that looks specifically at blood vessels. It provides detailed images of arteries and can be useful in detecting vascular problems. However, it might not be the first choice for initial evaluation, especially when quicker, less expensive, and equally informative tests are available, like the duplex scan.

 

Option C. Digital subtraction angiography: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is an invasive procedure that involves injecting a contrast medium into the blood vessels and taking X-ray images. It provides detailed visualization of the inner structures of blood vessels and is particularly useful for planning interventions. However, due to its invasive nature, it is typically done if planning a vascular intervention like balloon dilation or stenting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Chronic smoking can cause peripheral arterial disease, which can present with bluish discoloration of the toe and intermittent claudication.
  • Duplex Scanning is a non-invasive technique that uses ultrasound to provide an image of the vessel and can be used to investigate this condition.
  • Duplex Scanning allows for detailed visualization of blood flow within the vessel, with different colors indicating changes in direction and velocity of flow.

choices.text: 10-year-old child with multi organ dysfunction syndrome
49-year-old alcoholic man with liver cirrhosis with 1 month abstinence
74-year-old woman with end stage renal disease

questions.text: In the case of a 37-year-old woman who has been declared brain dead and whose family has agreed to donate her organs, who would be the most suitable or optimal candidate to receive the organs? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 31-year-old women with renal failure

 

This candidate is closer in age to the donor, and if her medical condition and compatibility allow for a successful kidney transplant, she may be the most suitable recipient for the kidney.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A 10-year-old child with multi-organ dysfunction syndrome: This candidate is likely in urgent need of multiple organ transplantation, and a younger recipient may generally have better long-term outcomes. However, etiology of multi-organ dysfunction is not provided, thereby the long term prognosis of the patient is uncertain.

 

Option B. A 49-year-old alcoholic man with liver cirrhosis with 1 month abstinence: While this candidate may benefit from a liver transplant, alcoholism can pose challenges to transplantation success. The one-month abstinence period is relatively short, and further evaluation of his liver condition and suitability for transplantation would be necessary.

 

Option C. A 74-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease: Given the age of the recipient and the fact that she has end-stage renal disease, a kidney transplant from the 37-year-old donor may not provide the best long-term outcomes. Older recipients may have a lower life expectancy, and the benefit of a kidney transplant may be less significant compared to younger recipients.

questions.text: A baby is brought to OPD for 10-week DPT vaccination appointment. He previously experienced a fever exceeding 40°C and had an inconsolable cry at 6 weeks old after receiving a vaccination. What would be the recommended course of action moving forward? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give DT vaccine

 

The child experienced a hypotonic-hyporesponsive episode or severe reaction (fever >40°C and persistent inconsolable crying) after the previous DPT dose. These are precautionary (not absolute contraindications) for pertussis-containing vaccines like DPT, but they warrant switching to a less reactogenic formulation.

 

DT (Diphtheria + Tetanus) vaccine is recommended in such cases, as it omits the pertussis component, which is most often responsible for such adverse events.

 

This allows continuation of diphtheria and tetanus protection while avoiding further adverse events from the pertussis component.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avoid DPT vaccination: Incorrect. DPT is contraindicated, but not all vaccinations should be avoided. The child should still receive protection against diphtheria and tetanus.

 

Option C. Give DPT vaccine: Incorrect. Given the prior adverse reaction, repeating DPT may risk more serious reactions. It’s prudent to avoid the pertussis component.

 

Option D. Defer by 4 weeks: Incorrect. There's no benefit in deferring the dose. The issue is not timing but the component that caused the reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe reactions (such as high fever >40.5°C, persistent inconsolable crying >3 hours, or hypotonic-hyporesponsive episodes) after a previous DPT dose are indications to withhold the pertussis component in future doses. The child should receive the DT vaccine instead.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient comes to the clinic with a history of rapidly enlarging swelling in her right breast for the last 15 days. During the physical examination, there was a local rise in temperature, and the lump was partially mobile over the chest wall. What could be the probable diagnosis for this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inflammatory carcinoma

 

Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) is a rare and aggressive form of breast cancer. It presents with rapid onset of swelling (edema), redness (erythema), and warmth due to its tendency to block the lymphatic vessels in the skin of the breast. This blockage leads to the classic "peau d'orange" appearance, resembling the skin of an orange. A local rise in temperature and rapid progression of symptoms (as in 15 days) can be consistent with inflammatory carcinoma. The tumor might be mobile initially, but as the disease progresses, it becomes fixed. Given the described symptoms and rapid onset, inflammatory carcinoma is a probable diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Giant fibroadenoma: Fibroadenomas are benign tumors composed of glandular and connective tissue. They are usually painless, mobile, and have a rubbery consistency. While they don't typically present with inflammation or a rapid onset of symptoms, giant fibroadenomas are larger than typical fibroadenomas (>5cm). They are seen in the 15 to 25 year old age group.

 

Option C. Phyllodes tumor: Phyllodes tumors are rare breast tumors that can be benign, borderline, or malignant. They can grow quickly and become quite large, and while they might be mobile, they do not typically present with inflammatory signs like warmth or redness.

 

Option D. Galactocele: A galactocele is a milk-filled cyst that can form in the breast. It typically presents in women who are lactating or have recently stopped lactating. While a galactocele can cause a lump in the breast, it doesn't cause inflammatory symptoms such as a local rise in temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the given scenario, the patient's rapid onset of disease and examination findings suggest inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, which is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer typically presents with brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (Peau d'orange appearance), along with a breast lump.
  • Skin biopsy is used to diagnose inflammatory breast cancer.
  • The treatment for inflammatory breast cancer includes combined-modality treatment, such as neoadjuvant chemotherapy, mastectomy, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy for ER-positive tumors, and Trastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a perineal approach for rectal prolapse? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ripstein’s procedure

 

The following surgical options are used to treat rectal prolapse:

 

This procedure involves the use of a prosthetic mesh that is placed around the mobilized rectum, with the attachment of the mesh to the presacral fascia (anterior) below the sacral promontory. It is performed using the abdominal approach, which is difficult but has a lower recurrence rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Delorme's operation: This surgical option involves the circumferential stripping of the rectal mucosa over the length of the prolapse. The underlying muscle is plicated with a series of sutures, and the excess rectal mucosa is excised. It is performed using the perineal approach and is associated with less morbidity but has a higher recurrence rate than the abdominal approach.

 

Option C. Thiersch operation: This surgical option involves placing a steel wire or nylon tape around the anal canal to manage partial rectal prolapse. It is largely obsolete now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation, and is rarely used.

 

Option D. Altemeier's procedure: This surgical option involves prolapsing the rectum through the anal canal and performing a full-thickness resection, incorporating any associated colonic prolapse. Restoration of colorectal continuity can be performed by hand-sewn/stapled anastomosis. It is the procedure of choice in patients presenting with incarcerated and strangulated prolapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ripstein's procedure is done for its management using the abdominal approach. The perineal approach is often preferred in elderly patients with high operative risk and limited life expectancy. It involves surgeries such as Delorme's mucosectomy and Thiersch's wiring, which have higher recurrence rates than the abdominal approach.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the emergency with a BP of 160/100 mg and a heart rate of 120 bpm. CECT done reveals a Stanford type A aortic dissection. What is the initial management of this given condition? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta blocker medication

 

Beta-blockers are used to control the heart rate and blood pressure in patients with aortic dissection. This helps in reducing the sheer force exerted on the wall of the aorta, which may help in preventing the progression of the dissection. Beta-blockers are the first-line medication for heart rate and blood pressure control in these patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. LMWH (Low Molecular Weight Heparin): This is an anticoagulant used to prevent or treat blood clots. In the context of an aortic dissection, it's not the initial management as it might increase the risk of bleeding within the dissection.

 

Option C. Surgical repair: Emergency surgical correction is the preferred treatment for Stanford type A (DeBakey type I and II) ascending aortic dissection. However, before surgery, it is crucial to stabilize the patient's vital signs, and beta-blockers play a significant role in this aspect.

 

Option D. Vitamin K inhibitors: These are anticoagulants that act by inhibiting vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. Like LMWH, they are not the initial management for aortic dissection due to the potential risk of bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of patients diagnosed with aortic dissection is Beta-blocker medication to control hypertension, along with pain management. The Preferred Beta-blocker drug is Esmolol.

 

Once hypertension is controlled, then definitive repair of aortic dissection is done based on Stanford type.

 

Stanford Classification:

 

  • Type A: This type involves the ascending aorta and possibly the descending aorta. It is considered the more dangerous type and often requires emergency surgery. Given its involvement with the ascending aorta, it's critical to manage promptly to avoid complications such as rupture or impairment of blood flow to vital organs.
  • Type B: Involves only the descending aorta.

 

Symptoms:

 

  • Severe, sudden, tearing chest pain
  • Pain that radiates to the back/scapula
  • Shortness of breath
  • Sweating
  • Weakness or paralysis on one side of the body (in rare cases)

 

Treatment:

 

  • Medical Management: Medications, especially beta-blockers, are often given initially to lower heart rate and blood pressure, reducing the force of blood against the aortic walls and potentially preventing further tearing.
  • Surgical Intervention: Emergency surgical correction is the preferred treatment for Stanford type A dissections. The surgery aims to repair the damaged section of the aorta and to prevent rupture or further dissection. Endovascular repair is preferred for Stanford B.

questions.text: All are seen in Cystic fibrosis except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Biliary atresia

 

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by dysfunction of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene, which leads to impaired chloride ion transport across cell membranes. This results in thick, viscous secretions in multiple organ systems. The hallmark finding is abnormally high sweat chloride levels (>60 mEq/L). In CF, secretions become thick and sticky, causing obstruction in various organs including the respiratory tract, pancreas, and intestines.

 

The manifestations of CF include:

 

  • Respiratory issues (recurrent respiratory infections, bronchiectasis, nasal polyps)
  • Gastrointestinal problems (meconium ileus, pancreatic insufficiency with steatorrhea, malabsorption)
  • Nutritional issues (failure to thrive, fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies)
  • Bleeding diathesis (due to vitamin K malabsorption as it's fat-soluble)

 

Biliary atresia is not associated with cystic fibrosis - they are two distinct conditions affecting different systems.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Biliary atresia is not a manifestation of cystic fibrosis, while meconium ileus, nasal polyps, and bleeding diathesis (due to vitamin K deficiency) are common findings in patients with cystic fibrosis.

 

Clinical features:

 

1. Respiratory system 

 

  • Repeated URTI 
  • Chronic cough 
  • Sputum 
  • Bronchiectasis 
  • Atelectasis
  • Nasal polyp 
  • H. influenza, S. aureus are the first organisms recovered from lung secretions  
  • Mortality in cystic fibrosis is due to Burkholderia 

 

2. Genitourinary 

 

  • Azoospermia 
  • Infertility 

 

Cong. B/I absence/obliteration of vas deferens 

 

3. Intestinal 

 

  • Meconium ileus is most common disorder at birth 
  • Distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (DIOS)
  • Rectal prolapse 

 

If sweat chlorides are normal, go for nasal transmembrane potential difference

 

4. Pancreatic 

 

  • Pancreatic: exocrine insufficiency-will lead to foul smelling stool 
  • Chronic pancreatitis

 

5. Hepatic:

 

  • Focal biliary cirrhosis 
  • Prolonged neonatal jaundice 

 

6. Nutritional:

 

  • Failure to thrive 
  • Hypoproteinemia + edema
  • Fat soluble vitamin def.

 

Salt loss syndrome: 

 

Acute salt depletion + chronic metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: Which of the following marked structure is damaged in respiratory distress syndrome? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

The structure marked as 2 represents Type II pneumocytes, which are crucial in the pathophysiology of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).

 

Key Points:

 

  • Type I pneumocytes (Marked as 1): These cells are large and flattened, making up the majority of the alveolar surface area. They form the thin barrier necessary for efficient gas exchange.
  • Type II pneumocytes (Marked as 2): These cells are rounded and responsible for producing surfactant, a substance composed of phospholipids and proteins that reduces surface tension within the alveoli. Surfactant is essential for preventing alveolar collapse (atelectasis) during exhalation. In respiratory distress syndrome, especially in premature infants, the deficiency or dysfunction of these Type II cells leads to insufficient surfactant production, causing the alveoli to collapse and resulting in severe breathing difficulties.
  • Endothelial cells of capillaries (Marked as 3): These cells line the blood vessels within the lungs and are involved in the exchange of gases between the blood and alveoli. They are not primarily involved in the pathogenesis of RDS.
  • Red Blood Cells (Marked as 4): These are the cells responsible for carrying oxygen from the lungs to the rest of the body and returning carbon dioxide to the lungs for exhalation. While essential for overall respiratory function, they are not the site of damage in RDS.

 

Clinical Relevance:

 

  • Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS): Commonly seen in premature infants, RDS is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant due to immature Type II pneumocytes. The lack of surfactant leads to increased surface tension, alveolar collapse, and severe respiratory distress. This condition is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in preterm infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type II pneumocytes are crucial for surfactant production and alveolar stability, and their dysfunction or immaturity is the primary cause of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in neonates.

questions.text: You are the on-call surgeon who is called for an emergency laparotomy for a patient with suspected bowel obstruction. During the surgery, which organ will you first visualize to determine if the obstruction is in the small or large bowel? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Caecum

 

  • The caecum is a pouch-like structure at the beginning of the colon. Visualizing the caecum first would indicate that the obstruction likely involves the large bowel if it is distended, helping to differentiate it from a small bowel obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The cecum is the first organ to be visualized to differentiate between small and large bowel obstruction in cases of intestinal obstruction.
  • Distension of the cecum will confirm large bowel involvement, while collapsed cecum implies small bowel obstruction.
  • Identifying a collapsed distal segment of the large bowel and its sequential proximal assessment leads to the identification of the cause.

questions.text: A trauma patient suffered a renal laceration with urine extravasation. He was managed conservatively. However, after a few days, he presented with a urinoma. The next best management for this patient would be? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ureteral stenting

 

The patient in the given question has renal laceration with urine extravasation, which classifies as grade 4 renal injury.

 

Ureteral stenting is a minimally invasive procedure that can help alleviate the obstruction and promote urine drainage, reducing the risk of infection and other complications associated with urinomas

 

Ureteral stenting involves the placement of a stent into the ureter to facilitate drainage of urine from the renal pelvis to the bladder. In the context of a urinoma, this can help alleviate the obstruction or urine accumulation, providing relief and preventing further complications. It is similar to placement of CBD stent via ERCP in cystic duct leak.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Surgical Repair and Exploration: Surgical repair and exploration may be considered if there is a significant structural or anatomical issue contributing to the urinoma that cannot be resolved through less invasive methods.

 

Option C. Observation: Observation alone may not be sufficient if the urinoma is causing discomfort, pain, or complications. It's crucial to address the urinoma promptly.

 

Option D. Percutaneous Drainage: Percutaneous drainage may be an option, but ureteral stenting is a more specific approach for managing urinomas resulting from ureteral obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A urinoma is a collection of urine that has leaked from the urinary tract and has accumulated outside its normal anatomical location. This condition typically occurs due to trauma, injury, or obstruction in the urinary system.

 

  1. Causes: Urinomas are usually caused by trauma, such as blunt abdominal or pelvic trauma, that leads to injury to the urinary collecting system. They can also result from urinary tract obstruction, infections, or surgical complications.
  2. Symptoms: Common symptoms of a urinoma may include abdominal or flank pain, fever, and swelling in the affected area. In some cases, urinomas may be asymptomatic and discovered incidentally during imaging studies.
  3. Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a combination of medical history, physical examination, and imaging studies, such as ultrasound, CT scans, or MRI, to visualize the urinoma and determine its size and location.

 

A persistent urinoma (a mass formed by encapsulated extravasated urine) should be managed with the placement of an internal ureteral stent.

 

Patients not cured by ureteral stenting may require percutaneous nephrostomy or transcutaneous drainage.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of prior neck radiation for lymphoma is diagnosed with 2 x 3 cm papillary thyroid cancer. No lymph node enlargement is present. What is the treatment? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total thyroidectomy

 

Explanation: 

 

Total thyroidectomy is now the preferred approach only for those differentiated thyroid cancers (DTCs) at higher risk for recurrence:

  • Tumor at least  4 cm 
  • Gross extrathyroidal extension 
  • Evidence of metastatic disease 
  • Radiation-induced DTC (mentioned in the history) 
  • Familial non-medullary thyroid cancer 
  • Multifocal bilateral DTC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemithyroidectomy:

 

  • History of radiation is a high-risk feature requiring total thyroidectomy
  • Hemithyroidectomy is reserved for low-risk, small unifocal tumors without risk factors

 

Option C. Hemithyroidectomy + MRND:

 

  • MRND is not indicated without clinical lymphadenopathy
  • MRND is mainly done for medullary thyroid cancer
  • Hemithyroidectomy is inadequate given the radiation history

 

Option D. Total Thyroidectomy + MRND:

 

  • No lymph node involvement noted
  • For papillary thyroid cancer without lymphadenopathy, central compartment (level VI) clearance may be done, but not MRND

 

Educational Objective: 

 

History of radiation exposure is an absolute indication for total thyroidectomy in differentiated thyroid cancer, regardless of tumor size.

questions.text: What is the rate of increment of head circumference in the first three months of life?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 cm per month

 

During the first three months of life, the head circumference of a baby increases by approximately 2 cm per month. This rapid growth is due to the significant brain development occurring during this period. After the first three months, the growth rate slows down. From three to six months of age, the head circumference increases by about 1 cm per month, and from six months to one year, it increases by about 0.5 cm per month.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The head circumference of a baby increases by approximately 2 cm per month during the first three months of life.

choices.text: Early discharge, skin to skin contact, prevent infection
Early discharge, skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding
Skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection
Early discharge, exclusive breastfeeding and prevent infection

questions.text: Which of the following are components of kangaroo mother care? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early discharge, skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding.

 

Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) is an essential practice for the care of low birthweight infants, particularly in resource-limited settings. The core components of KMC include:

 

  • Skin-to-skin contact: The baby is placed between the mother's breasts in an upright position. The baby's hips are abducted and flexed in a "frog position," and the arms are also flexed. This close contact helps regulate the baby's temperature, breathing, and heart rate.
  • Exclusive breastfeeding: KMC promotes exclusive breastfeeding, which is crucial for the baby's nutrition and immune protection.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care: KMC supports the early discharge of stable low birthweight infants from the hospital, allowing continued care at home with close follow-up.

 

These components are fundamental to the success of KMC, leading to improved survival rates and health outcomes for low birthweight infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early discharge, skin to skin contact, prevent infection: Includes "prevent infection," which is an essential aspect of general neonatal care but not a specific component of KMC. KMC primarily focuses on skin-to-skin contact, breastfeeding, and early discharge.

 

Option C. Skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection: Also mentions "prevent infection," which, while important, is not a direct component of KMC.

 

Option D. Early discharge, exclusive breastfeeding and prevent infection: Includes "prevent infection" instead of "skin-to-skin contact," making it incorrect, as skin-to-skin contact is a critical element of KMC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) involves skin-to-skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, and early discharge, focusing on the care of low birthweight infants.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with weight for height less than minus 1 SD & height for age is minus 2 SD. What is the best possible assessment?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic malnutrition

 

Chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, is indicated by a height for age that is significantly below the normal. According to World Health Organization (WHO) standards, a height for age that is less than minus 2 standard deviations (SD) from the median of the reference population is indicative of stunting. In this question, the child has a height for age of minus 2 SD, which points to chronic malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute malnutrition: This is typically indicated by a significant weight loss over a short period, reflected in weight for height measurements. A weight for height less than minus 3 SD from the median would indicate severe acute malnutrition, but in this case, the weight for height is less than minus 1 SD, which is not sufficient to diagnose acute malnutrition.

 

Option C. Acute on chronic malnutrition: This would be indicated if the child had signs of both chronic malnutrition (height for age less than minus 2 SD) and significant recent weight loss. However, the weight for height is only less than minus 1 SD, not indicative of acute malnutrition.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect as chronic malnutrition is clearly indicated by the height for age of minus 2 SD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic malnutrition is diagnosed when a child's height for age is less than minus 2 standard deviations from the median of the reference population, indicating stunting.

choices.text: Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indicator of fetal lung maturity?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells

 

The Nile blue test is a laboratory test used to assess fetal lung maturity by staining desquamated fetal cells obtained from amniotic fluid. The correct interpretation of this test is that if more than 50% of the cells stain orange, it indicates pulmonary maturity. Therefore, the presence of more than 50% blue cells, as mentioned in Option D, suggests immature lungs rather than maturity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lecithin-sphingomyelin ratio > 2.0: The Lecithin-sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio is a well-established method for assessing fetal lung maturity. A ratio greater than 2.0 typically indicates mature fetal lungs.

 

Option B. Positive shake test: The shake test, also known as the foam stability test, assesses the presence of surfactant in amniotic fluid. A positive shake test, indicated by the formation of stable bubbles, suggests fetal lung maturity.

 

Option C. Increased phosphatidyl glycerol: The presence of phosphatidylglycerol in amniotic fluid is another indicator of lung maturity, particularly in pregnancies complicated by diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:


The presence of more than 50% orange cells in the Nile blue test indicates fetal lung maturity, whereas more than 50% blue cells suggest immaturity.

questions.text: A female presented with an ulcerated breast lump. Nipple retraction was seen, with some warmth and redness. On biopsy, it was diagnosed as invasive ductal carcinoma. According to AJCC 8th Ed., which of these correctly represents the stage? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T4b

 

In the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) 8th edition staging system, the classification of breast cancer stages is detailed based on tumor size, lymph node involvement, and the presence of metastasis.

 

The presentation of an ulcerated breast lump, nipple retraction, warmth, and redness suggests skin involvement, which is characteristic of a T4 classification. Specifically, the presence of ulceration and skin involvement corresponds to T4b. T4b is used when there is skin involvement in the form of ulceration, satellite skin nodules, or peau d’orange (skin changes resembling the texture of an orange).

 

While there is the possibility of inflammatory breast cancer due to the warmth and redness, the key feature here is ulceration, which is more indicative of T4b. Inflammatory breast cancer would correspond to a T4d classification, characterized by more extensive skin changes like diffuse erythema and edema (peau d'orange) involving more than one-third of the breast, often with underlying invasive ductal carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage IV with N1-N2 involvement: This is incorrect as there is no evidence of distant metastasis (M1), which is required for a Stage IV classification. The presence of regional lymph node involvement (N1-N2) alone does not justify a Stage IV classification.

 

Option C. Stage IIIB: This could be considered if the case were inflammatory breast cancer, but based on the ulceration and other features described, T4b is more appropriate unless additional evidence of inflammatory changes was present.

 

Option D. It cannot be M1: This statement is partially correct as the case does not mention any distant metastasis (M1), but it doesn’t address the primary tumor stage, which is the focus of the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulceration of a breast lump with skin involvement typically corresponds to T4b in the AJCC 8th edition staging system for breast cancer. It is essential to differentiate between T4b and T4d (inflammatory breast cancer) based on the clinical presentation and pathological findings.

questions.text:
A child is brought to the casualty with a history of choking. On examination, there is decreased air entry in the left lung. What would be the correct management? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Bronchoscopy
  2. Computed tomography scan
  3. ICD insertion
  4. Chest x-ray
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 4

 

A child presenting with a history of choking and decreased air entry in the left lung is highly suggestive of a foreign body lodged in the left bronchus. The correct management steps include:

 

1. Bronchoscopy: This is the gold standard for both the diagnosis and removal of the foreign body. Rigid bronchoscopy is typically performed by a specialist, such as an otolaryngologist or pulmonologist, to visualize and extract the foreign body.

 

4. Chest X-ray: This is an essential initial investigation to assess for the presence of a foreign body. Although many foreign bodies are radiolucent, secondary findings such as air trapping, obstructive emphysema, atelectasis, asymmetric hyperinflation, mediastinal shift, and consolidation can be indicative of foreign body aspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

2. CT scan: While a CT scan has high sensitivity and specificity for detecting radiolucent foreign bodies, it is not routinely performed in this situation due to the high radiation exposure, especially in children.

 

3. ICD insertion: Insertion of an intercostal drain (ICD) is not indicated unless there is clinical evidence of pneumothorax or other complications that require it. A chest X-ray is essential before deciding on this intervention.

 

Clinical Approach:

 

  • A detailed history and physical examination are critical when a child presents with choking.
  • A chest X-ray should be performed to assess for secondary signs of foreign body aspiration.
  • Bronchoscopy should be conducted even if imaging is negative but clinical suspicion remains high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child with suspected foreign body aspiration, a chest X-ray and bronchoscopy are the key steps for diagnosis and management. Bronchoscopy allows for both visualization and removal of the foreign body.

choices.text: Give oral fluids and zinc supplementation only and ask mother to come back if danger sign develops.
Give oral fluids and ask mother to continue the same and visit again the next day.
Consider severe dehydration start IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to higher centre.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. No history of fever or blood in stools. The mother says he is irritable and eagerly drinks water if given. On examination, eyes are sunken and in the skin pinch test, the skin retracted within two seconds but not immediately. What treatment is advised for the child? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Give oral fluids and zinc supplementation only and ask mother to come back if danger sign develops

 

In this question, the child has some dehydration because he or she is restless and irritable, drinks water freely, has sluggish skin retraction (2 seconds) on skin pinch test, and has sunken eyes.

 

Treatment according to the WHO Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Diseases (IMNCI) guideline plan B.

 

  • Oral rehydration therapy
  • Zinc supplements,
  • Sustained breastfeeding

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Give oral fluids and ask mother to continue the same and visit again the next day: Zinc supplementation is an important treatment protocol for diarrhea. In this option that point was missing, therefore this is not the right option.

 

Option C. Consider severe dehydration start IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to higher centre: If the child was having refusal to drink with skin pinch more than 2 seconds, we could have thought of severe dehydration. Therefore this is not the right option.

 

Option D. Wait and observe: Child is eagerly drinking which is a feature of some dehydration, therefore, wait and observe is not the right option.

 

Educational Objective:


In a child with some dehydration, the recommended treatment includes oral rehydration therapy, zinc supplementation, and continued breastfeeding, with instructions to return if danger signs develop.

questions.text: Enzyme deficient in pompe’s disease is: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha 1, 4 glucosidase

 

  • Pompe's disease is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (also known as acid maltase), an enzyme involved in the breakdown of glycogen. Pompe's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Glucose 6 phosphatase: This is not the correct enzyme. Glucose 6 phosphatase deficiency is associated with von Gierke's disease, a glycogen storage disorder. It primarily affects the liver and kidney.

 

Option C. Muscle phosphorylase: Muscle phosphorylase is associated with McArdle's disease, a glycogen storage disorder affecting skeletal muscles. It is not the enzyme deficient in Pompe's disease.

 

Option D. Phosphofructokinase: Phosphofructokinase is associated with Tarui's disease, another glycogen storage disorder. It is not the enzyme deficient in Pompe's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the enzymatic basis of Pompe's disease, recognizing that it is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase). Be aware of the clinical manifestations and biochemical abnormalities associated with Pompe's disease, which is characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with leg pain. She had fever and cough 3 days prior. Currently, there is pain on palpation of the calf muscles. Reflexes and other clinical examinations are normal. Lab test reveals CK levels of 2000 IU. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Viral myositis

 

The clinical presentation described is most consistent with viral myositis. Viral myositis is an inflammation of the muscles caused by viral infection, often following an upper respiratory tract illness. The condition is characterized by the following features:

 

  • Recent viral illness: The history of fever and cough 3 days prior suggests a preceding viral infection, which is a common trigger for viral myositis.
  • Leg pain and muscle tenderness: Viral myositis often presents with significant muscle soreness, especially in the calf muscles, leading to pain on palpation.
  • Elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels: The CK level of 2000 IU indicates muscle injury or inflammation, which is consistent with viral myositis.
  • Normal reflexes and neurological examination: This helps differentiate viral myositis from other conditions like Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) or Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which would typically present with abnormal reflexes or progressive muscle weakness.

 

Influenza is a common viral cause of myositis, particularly in children. The muscle pain typically begins 1-7 days after the onset of the viral illness and may lead to difficulty walking, often with a characteristic toe-walking gait due to involvement of the gastrocnemius-soleus muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duchenne: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness, typically presenting with proximal muscle weakness, calf pseudohypertrophy, and elevated CK levels. However, it does not present acutely following a viral illness and usually starts earlier in life.

 

Option C. GBS (Guillain-Barré Syndrome): GBS is an autoimmune condition that causes ascending paralysis, starting with weakness in the legs. Reflexes are usually diminished or absent in GBS, unlike the normal reflexes observed in this case.

 

Option D. Dermatomyositis: Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory muscle disease characterized by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. It usually presents with chronic, progressive weakness rather than acute pain following a viral illness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viral myositis is characterized by muscle pain, especially in the calves, following a viral infection, with elevated CK levels and normal reflexes, distinguishing it from other neuromuscular conditions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with Graves' disease with eye signs and enlarged thyroid is scheduled for a total thyroidectomy. What medication can be administered in the preoperative period to minimize intraoperative bleeding in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Potassium iodide

 

Potassium iodide, which can be given 10 days before the surgery to reduce intraoperative bleeding during total thyroidectomy. This is because iodide alone produces transient remission and may reduce vascularity, thereby marginally improving safety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can be used to prepare the patient for surgery by inhibiting the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 and causing beta-adrenergic blockade. However, it is not specifically used to reduce intraoperative bleeding during thyroidectomy. It is beneficial in thyroid storm.

 

Option C. Propylthiouracil: Propylthiouracil is an antithyroid drug that inhibits thyroid synthesis and peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. It is used to render the patient euthyroid before surgery, but it is not specifically used to reduce intraoperative bleeding.

 

Option D. Betamethasone: Betamethasone is a glucocorticoid that reduces the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. However, it is not used preoperatively in thyroidectomy to reduce intraoperative bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Graves' disease is an autoimmune disorder that results in an overactive thyroid gland, known as hyperthyroidism. In this condition, the immune system attacks the thyroid gland, causing it to produce more thyroid hormone than the body needs. As a result, the thyroid gland becomes hyperactive, leading to various symptoms associated with hyperthyroidism. Graves' disease is the most prevalent cause of hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby with intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxoplasmosis

 

The clinical presentation of intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus is characteristic of congenital toxoplasmosis. Congenital toxoplasmosis is caused by the protozoan parasite Toxoplasma gondii. The classic triad associated with this condition includes:

 

  1. Intracranial diffuse calcifications
  2. Chorioretinitis
  3. Hydrocephalus

 

These features are clearly visible in the provided imaging, where multiple calcifications (white dots) are seen throughout the brain, which is typical of toxoplasmosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV infection in a congenital context typically presents with periventricular calcifications rather than diffuse intracranial calcifications. This means the calcifications are primarily located around the brain's ventricles rather than spread diffusely throughout.

 

 

Option C. Zika virus: Zika virus infection can lead to gray matter and white matter calcifications, which are distinct from the diffuse calcifications seen in toxoplasmosis. Zika is also associated with microcephaly and contractures, which are not noted in this case.

 

Option D. Rubella: Congenital rubella syndrome can present with various symptoms such as cataracts, heart defects, and hearing impairment, but it is not typically associated with intracranial calcifications or hydrocephalus, making it an unlikely diagnosis for this presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key fact to memorize is that the triad of intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus is indicative of congenital toxoplasmosis.

 

Remember:

 

  • Periventricular calcification – Congenital CMV infection
  • Intracranial diffuse calcification - Congenital toxoplasmosis
  • Gray matter-white matter (GMWM) Calcification – Congenital Zika virus

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with weight loss and fever. The patient reports a history of blood in the stool and vomiting two weeks ago. Upon examination, tenderness is noted in the right hypochondrium along with an enlarged liver (hepatomegaly). An abdominal CT scan reveals a lesion in the right liver lobe characterized by irregular borders, several partitions, and varied densities. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amoebic liver abscess

 

The most probable diagnosis in this case is C) Amoebic liver abscess.

 

1. Clinical Presentation:

 

  • The patient presents with weight loss and fever, which are common symptoms associated with liver abscesses.
  • A history of blood in the stool and vomiting two weeks ago may suggest an underlying gastrointestinal infection, likely to be amebic colitis.

 

2. Physical Examination Findings:

 

  • Tenderness in the right hypochondrium (upper right abdomen) suggests liver involvement.
  • Enlarged liver (hepatomegaly) is a common finding in liver abscesses.

 

3. Imaging Findings:

 

  • The description of the lesion on the abdominal CT scan is characteristic of an amoebic liver abscess. These abscesses typically have irregular borders, several partitions (internal septations), and varied densities due to necrotic tissue and pus formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyogenic liver abscess: Can also cause similar symptoms and imaging findings but will often present with high grade fever and chills, and is usually multiple.

 

Option B. Hydatid cyst: Typically presents as a well-defined cystic lesion on imaging and is caused by the Echinococcus parasite. It will not be preceded by a colitis type of event. It's less likely given the description of irregular borders and partitions in the lesion.

 

Option D. Hemangiomas: Hemangiomas are usually benign vascular tumors and are unlikely to cause the presented symptoms or imaging findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of clinical symptoms, physical examination findings, and the characteristic imaging features of an irregular, partitioned lesion in the liver makes amoebic liver abscess the most probable diagnosis in this case

 

 

ANCHOVY SAUCE – STERILE PUS SEEN IN AMEBIC LIVER ABSCESS

questions.text: Match the condition with the appropriate diagnostic test: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A 1, B 2, C 3, D 4

 

  1. Hirschsprung's disease is diagnosed by rectal biopsy, which is the gold standard diagnostic test for this condition.
  2. Posterior urethral valve is diagnosed by micturating cystourethrogram, which is a radiographic imaging test of the bladder and urethra during voiding.
  3. Choledochal cyst is diagnosed by MRCP, which is a non-invasive imaging test that uses magnetic resonance imaging to visualize the biliary tree.
  4. Intussusception is diagnosed by CT scan, which is a diagnostic imaging test that provides detailed images of the abdominal organs and structures.

 

Explanation:

 

A. Hirschsprung's disease: This is a congenital disorder in which nerve cells (ganglion cells) are absent from a segment of the bowel, usually the rectum or sigmoid colon, leading to a functional obstruction. Infants with Hirschsprung's typically have difficulty with bowel movements within the first days of life. The symptoms can include constipation, abdominal distension, and vomiting. It is diagnosed often in the neonatal period with a barium enema and confirmed with suction rectal biopsy showing the absence of ganglion cells.

 

B. Posterior urethral valve (PUV): PUV is a congenital malformation in male child where an abnormality of the posterior urethra prevents urine outflow. This can lead to urinary obstruction, distension of the bladder, and can subsequently cause damage to the kidneys. Common symptoms include weak urine stream, difficulty in urination, recurrent urinary tract infections, and failure to thrive. Diagnosis is usually made with a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

 

C. Choledochal cyst: This is a congenital dilation of the bile ducts, often causing obstruction. Patients may present with the classic triad of abdominal pain, jaundice, and an abdominal mass, although not all these signs may be evident. Over time, choledochal cysts can lead to complications like cholangitis, pancreatitis, or even malignancy. Diagnosis is typically done with imaging like ultrasound or MRCP, and definitive treatment is surgical removal.

 

D. Intussusception: This is a medical condition in which a part of the intestine telescopes into another section, leading to bowel obstruction. It is the most common cause of bowel obstruction in children between the ages of 6 months and 3 years. Symptoms include sudden, severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and "currant jelly" stools (due to mucus and blood). The diagnosis can often be made with an ultrasound or CT abdomen showing the characteristic "target sign" and is typically treated with high pressure enema, although some cases may require surgical intervention.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are independently false statements.
The assertion is independently a true statement, but the reason is independently a false statement.
Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.
Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion.

questions.text:
Choose the most appropriate answer: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

Assertion: In phenylketonuria, the urine has a mousy odor.

 

Reason: The serum levels of tyrosine, dopamine, and norepinephrine are decreased in phenylketonuria.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.

 

  • Assertion: The statement that "In phenylketonuria, the urine has a mousy odor" is true. The mousy or musty odor of the urine in phenylketonuria (PKU) is due to the accumulation of phenylacetate, one of the metabolites of phenylalanine.
  • Reason: The statement that "The serum levels of tyrosine, dopamine, and norepinephrine are decreased in phenylketonuria" is also true. Phenylketonuria is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. Consequently, low levels of tyrosine lead to reduced synthesis of catecholamines such as dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine.

 

However, the reason provided is not the correct explanation for the assertion. The mousy odor in PKU is directly related to the accumulation of phenylacetate, not to the decreased levels of tyrosine or catecholamines.

 

Detailed Mechanism:

 

  • Phenylketonuria (PKU): PKU is an inborn error of metabolism caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase or, less commonly, a defect in enzymes responsible for producing tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4). This defect results in impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine, leading to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites, such as phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate, which are excreted in the urine.
  • Tyrosine and Catecholamine Synthesis: Tyrosine is a precursor for the synthesis of catecholamines, including dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine. In PKU, the deficiency of tyrosine leads to reduced synthesis of these neurotransmitters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In phenylketonuria, the mousy odor of urine is due to the accumulation of phenylacetate, while decreased levels of tyrosine and catecholamines are a result of the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. However, the two phenomena are not causally related.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby was brought to the hospital with complaints of poor feeding and abnormal twitching of his lower limb. On examination, he has fever with fontanelle bulging and the child was lethargic. The most probable cause is: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meningitis

 

Poor eating, fever, convulsions, a bulging fontanelle, and lethargy are all symptoms of meningitis.

 

Meningococcus, Streptococcus pneumonia, or Haemophilus influenza type b can all cause bacterial meningitis. General symptoms include fever, lethargy, unwillingness to feed, vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Febrile seizure: Patient should have a history of high grade fever associated with seizures.

 

Option C. Pseudotumor cerebri: This is the most common type of focal seizure present in sleep. Age group 3-10 yr, resolve by adolescence. Start at night in the form of buccal throat tingling, tonic clonic contraction of one side with preserved consciousness.

 

Option D. Intracranial hemorrhage: Patient should have history of any trauma

 

Seizures and localised neurological symptoms are possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Poor eating, fever, convulsions, a bulging fontanelle, and lethargy are all symptoms of meningitis.

choices.text: Most of the grafts are multi-visceral grafts.
It is not widely used due to vigorous rejection reactions.
The most dangerous complication is sepsis.
The most common indication is the ischemia

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about intestinal transplantation: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most of the grafts are multi-visceral grafts

 

This statement is incorrect. While multi-visceral transplantation, which includes the intestine along with other abdominal organs like the liver and pancreas, can occur, it is not the most common type of intestinal transplantation. Isolated intestinal transplantation, where only the intestine is transplanted, is more common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is not widely used due to vigorous rejection reactions: This statement is correct. Intestinal transplantation is not as widely performed as other organ transplants like kidney or liver transplantation because the intestine is known to trigger vigorous rejection reactions.

 

Option C. The most dangerous complication is sepsis: This statement is correct. Sepsis is indeed a significant and life-threatening complication associated with intestinal transplantation. The immunosuppressive medications used to prevent rejection can increase the risk of infections, including sepsis.

 

Option D. The most common indication is ischemia. (Correct): Ischemia is one of the common indications for intestinal transplantation. It is often used when patients have suffered from ischemic bowel disease and other treatments have been ineffective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multi-visceral grafts are rarely used in intestinal transplantation. The most common intestinal graft is small bowel graft, with or without the colon or a combined liver and small bowel graft.

 

All the other statements are correct.

 

Small bowel transplantation is the final treatment option when the outcome of reconstruction and lengthening procedures are unsatisfactory.

 

The small bowel transplant is highly immunogenic as it contains a large amount of gut-associated lymphoid tissue, donor dendritic cells, and macrophages. Acute rejection has been reported in 56-75% of patients, with small bowel transplant limiting the overall survival to only one-third of recipients.

questions.text: Which is a not a risk factor for Carcinoma of Gall bladder? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyp <10 mm

 

Gallbladder polyps are growths that emerge from the lining of the gallbladder. Those that are smaller than 10 mm are generally considered less likely to be cancerous. The risk of cancer increases with the size of the polyp, especially if it is larger than 10 mm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Porcelain gallbladder: This condition is characterized by calcification of the gallbladder wall. It has been associated with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer.

 

Option B. Primary sclerosing cholangitis: This is a chronic biliary disease marked by inflammation and fibrosis of the bile ducts. People with primary sclerosing cholangitis have an elevated risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma and to a lesser extent, gallbladder cancer, especially if they develop gallbladder polyps.

 

Option D. Gallstone >3 cm: Large gallstones, especially those larger than 3 cm, have been linked with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While porcelain gallbladders and large gallstones are established risk factors for gallbladder cancer, and primary sclerosing cholangitis has a known association with gallbladder malignancies, small gallbladder polyps (less than 10 mm) typically represent a lower risk for cancer.

questions.text:
What are the components of Nada's Minor Criteria? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Systolic mumur Grade 3
  2. Diastolic murmur
  3. Abnormal second heart sound
  4. Abnormal BP
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 and 4

 

Nada’s criteria is used for detection of CHD on the basis of clinical evaluation.

 

 

Presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria suggest presence of heart disease.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In Nada’s criteria for detecting congenital heart disease, minor criteria include an abnormal second heart sound and abnormal blood pressure. The presence of one major or two minor criteria suggests the presence of heart disease.

questions.text:
A 8-year-old child weighing 26 kg presents with a history of loose stools for 2 days. On examination, there is severe dehydration. Laboratory investigations are as follows. What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines? (NEET PG 2023)

 

RBS → 550

рН → 7.01

Na+ → 158

Urine glucose → 3+

Urine Ketone → +ve
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Manage ABC, NS 10-20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

 

The given clinical scenario points to diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis

 

According to the ISPAD guidelines shown below, first the patient has to be classified for shock/Moderate dehydration/minimal dehydration. In this given scenario, child is in shock, so, the initial management includes management of the airway, breathing, and circulation (ABC) and fluid replacement along with an IV bolus of 20 mL/kg 0.9% Normal saline, followed by an IV insulin infusion of 0.05 - 0.1 U/kg/hr, 1 hour after starting fluid replacement therapy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr.: First we will give fluids and then after one hour we will give insulin

 

Option C. Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr: The fluid volume of 10 mL/kg is insufficient for severe dehydration and shock. The correct volume is 20 mL/kg.

 

Option D. Manage ABC, NS 30 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour: This option provides an insufficient fluid volume and delays insulin administration, which is not recommended in severe cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) in children, the initial treatment includes managing ABC, administering 20 mL/kg of 0.9% normal saline, and starting an insulin infusion at 0.1 U/kg/hr.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presented with a painless breast lump measuring 6.2 X 4.5 cm in the left upper outer quadrant and no axillary nodes. Core cut biopsy showed ductal carcinoma in situ. She underwent tumor resection with adequate margins and postoperative H&E showed DCIS with intermediate-grade necrosis and with 6-mm clearance on margins. What would be the next step in treatment? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

According to Silverstein Van Nuys prognostic index which is used for DCIS, the total score is 9, and the patient would require adjuvant radiotherapy.

 

Age: 43 years (score 2), size: 62mm (score 3), clearance margin: 6mm (score 2) with intermediate-grade necrosis (score 2).

 

The Silverstein Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) is a prognostic tool used in the management of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of the breast. DCIS is a non-invasive form of breast cancer, and the VNPI helps guide treatment decisions by assessing the risk of local recurrence.

 

The VNPI combines three significant predictors of local recurrence:

 

  1. Tumor size: The size of the DCIS lesion.
  2. Margin width: The width of clear tissue margins around the tumor after surgical resection.
  3. Pathologic classification: The histopathological characteristics of the DCIS, including features like grade and necrosis.

 

Scores on the VNPI typically range from 1 (best prognosis) to 3 (worst prognosis), with higher scores indicating a higher risk of local recurrence

 

The VNPI assists oncologists and surgeons in determining the appropriate treatment approach for patients with DCIS. For example, patients with a lower VNPI score may be candidates for less aggressive treatment, while those with a higher score may require more intensive therapies such as radiation therapy or mastectomy.

 

Score <7: No further treatment

 

Score 7-9: Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

Score >9: Simple mastectomy
